bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Ida E. Kissinger, August 1, 1941 [Enclosed in 06306001]

div1.p: Kean recommends to Kissinger that her husband be moved to a veteran's hospital in Indianapolis.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Ida E. Kissinger, August 1, 1941 [Enclosed in 06306001]
div1.opener:
Copy-
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Aug. 1st 1941
Mrs. John R. Kissinger
Huntington, Ind.
Dear Madam
div1.p:
I have heard from Dr. P.S. Hench,
of the Mayo Clinic of the calamity
which has be fallen your husband, &
I feel deep sympathy for him and
for you, who have the heavy respons-
ibility of his care. I was the Chief
Surgeon at Marianao at the time he
made his gallant offer to my friend
Major Walter Reed and knew of it
before he was bitten by the yellow fever mosquito,
AC
K
as an Army doctor I know that one
woman cannot give proper care and
attention to a paralyzed patient and that
the proper and only place for him is in
a hospital. So I wish to be sure that
you understand that the government offers
to its veterans first class hospital
treatment in hospitals in various parts
of the country free. These are not
under the Army but under the
veterans administration, the Hdqrs. of
which is here in Washington. I have
asked the veterans administration to
send you a blank form with in-
structions just what to do, to
secure this service for your good
husband, who has a right to it, and
must surely need it.
div1.closer: Yours truly (Signed) J. R. Kean (Brig. Gen. Ret.)
